author: ETV Bharat
title: Virat Kohli Fails In First Innings Of Ranji Trophy Return, Departs On 6 Runs
text:
Delhi: India batting stalwart Virat Kohli failed on his Ranji Trophy return after 13 years as he got bowled on just 6 runs in the first innings of Delhi's innings against Railways at Arun Jaitely Stadium here on Friday, January 31.
Kohli was dismissed for six off 15 balls, losing his off-stump to right-arm pacer Himanshu Sangwan. Pacer Himanshu Sangwan bowled fuller length, angling in just outside off stump. Kohli came out of the crease and went for the straight drive, but left a gap between bat and pad. The ball rushed through to clean Kohli up after also seaming in and bouncing nicely and flattened the off stump.
Virat Kohli Wicket Vs Railway Ranji Trophy Match
â€” yogendracrick (@cricketlover672)[pic.twitter.com/Y3hdYcC2kC][January 31, 2025]
However, on a similar delivery, just off the previous ball, the 36-year-old had whacked the bowler for a boundary down the ground. However, Kohli perished attempting a similar shot as the ball swung into him more than it had in the previous delivery or he assumed. Soon after Kohli's dismissal, fans were seen getting up from their seats and leaving the stadium in large numbers in disappointment.
Aura, fans leaving after Virat Kohli wicket.
â€” Cricket World ðŸ (@Sunny29548707)[pic.twitter.com/QbwU6gDX6y][January 31, 2025]
The 36-year-old has returned to play in the Ranji Trophy after almost 13 years, having last featured in the tournament in November 2012 against Uttar Pradesh in Ghaziabad.
The opening day of the match between Delhi and Railways saw over 15,000 fans coming to the stadium to watch their favourite cricketer in action. However, they were denied a glimpse of Kohli batting as Delhi skipper Ayush Badoni won the toss and opted to field first.

Scorecard â–¶ï¸[https://t.co/IhwXam37gl][pic.twitter.com/FXnCSzmOfC][January 31, 2025]
Delhi bowlers did well to restrict Railways to 241 but lost a wicket soon. However, opener Sanat Sangwan and Yash Dhull continued to bat by Stumps, with Kohli set to walk in at the fall of the next batter.
The crowd went delirious when Yash Dhull was dismissed in the first session of the second day by Rahul Sharma. The air was brimming with excitement and anticipation as Kohli walked into a rousing reception.
Shortly after cleaning up Kohli, Himanshu sent Sanat Sangwan - who was at the other end when Kohli was in the middle - was dismissed for 30 runs off 81 balls.

author: TN City Desk
title: Delhi FOg: Red Alert Sounded For Delhi-NCR As Dense Fog Causes Visibility Woes | Delhi News, Times Now
text: IMD Issues Red Alert For Delhi-NCR Amid Dense Fog The cautionary alert for Friday has been put in place to dissuade people from venturing out during the 4 am to 10 am window, as this period has witnessed car pile-ups and fatalities in Delhi-NCR over the past three days amid worsening fog conditions. Dense fog in Delhi-NCR, ANI. New Delhi: The weather department has issued a red alert for dense dense fog on Friday, advising the public to refrain from traveling in their vehicles between 4 am and 10 am, unless absolutely necessary. When visibility drops below 50 meters due to fog, it is classified as very dense fog. The cautionary alert for Friday has been put in place to dissuade people from venturing out during the 4 am to 10 am window, as this period has witnessed car pile-ups and fatalities in Delhi-NCR over the past three days amid worsening fog conditions. Kuldeep Srivastava, a scientist at IMD, explained that the improvement in fog conditions on Thursday was attributed to overnight winds in various areas, reaching speeds of up to 8 kmph. However, experts anticipate a return of very dense fog on Friday morning as the wind speed is expected to drop. In terms of temperatures, the maximum recorded at Safdarjung, the city's base station, was 21.4 degrees Celsius, slightly above normal, while the minimum temperature was 8.4 degrees Celsius. The average Air Quality Index (AQI) stood at 350, a decrease from the previous day's 380. The IITM's air quality early warning system warned of unfavourable conditions for pollutant dispersion, with a likelihood of further deterioration if firecrackers are burnt on December 31. The system also indicated east-southeast winds at 6-4 kmph with partly cloudy skies and dense to very dense fog in the morning on December 29. In Gurgaon, visibility plummeted to 50 meters on Thursday due to dense fog, prompting the IMD to issue a 'yellow alert' until December 31. Dense to very dense fog is anticipated across the state from December 28 to January 1, with a recorded minimum temperature of 9.8 degrees Celsius. The city's minimum temperature is expected to remain around 10-11 degrees Celsius until January 3, while the maximum is projected to range between 22-23 degrees Celsius.
